Shares of ON Semiconductor  were largely flat on Monday after third-quarter results beat estimates.Outlook: The company expects fourth-quarter revenue to be between $1.71B and $1.81B (midpoint at $1.76B), versus the consensus revenue estimate of $1.78B. Meanwhile, adjusted earnings per share are anticipated in the range of $0.92 to $1.04 (midpoint at $0.98) compared to consensus estimate of $1 per share.Third quarter revenue fell about 19% year-over-year to around $1.76B, while non-GAAP EPS tumbled nearly 28% year-on-year to $0.99. However, both top and bottom-line numbers surpassed analysts expectations."With third-quarter results above expectations, we remain focused on delivering consistent results in the current environment through execution and prudent financial management," said Hassane El-Khoury, President and CEO of ON Semi.

There is nothing commodity about SiC.  These automotive manufacturers design a platform and then run multiple years with the same platform across multiple models with a very high cost to qualify alternative manufacturers.  In addition, driver assist modules, cabin control modules and entertainment features are the same for EV/Gas/Diesel.  You seem to keep focus on one portion of a broad spectrum of products offered by ON.  They support Solar/Energy Storage/Industrial Automation/Robotics/Connected Lighting/5G/Base Station/Server/Telecom/Cloud/Medical/Defense.... This a why they have not had the PnL swings of many of the other semiconductor manufacturers.

The market is realizing that ON's SIC semis are becoming a commodity product in a market where China is ramping production while end markets are contracting--and with the very real possibility when Dony or Kamala Tariff lays more tariffs on China ON will lose 35% of its biz!

Mop-boy jammie is color blind; he thinks redflags are green buy signals! Red flags everywhere for ON! Volkswagen, Mercedes, Aston Martin, and BMW have all recently slashed their forecasts. The broader economic landscape for Western automobile companies is dire as high interest rates crush demand, EV programs hemorrhage cash, and demand in China wanes.

As usual, bayoubrainhemorrhage-star lard is either intentionally misleading or displaying his sheer ignorance. 

Silicon Carbide SUBSTRATE is oversupplied and commoditized, not the chips. The chips are not easy to produce and competition is a good thing. 

ON doesn’t sell substrate to the open market but they do buy some so they’re a beneficiary of that dynamic. WOLF on the other hand, which he loved and pumped over $100, is an external supplier of substrate and they will be toast.
EU jacks Chinese EVs to 45% in a crashing ev market. Bad news for ON!

From 2 years ago! And it's now happening! During last month’s Electronica trade show in Munich, Jochen Hanebeck, CEO of Infineon Technologies, noted, “I see China’s intent to leapfrog silicon power semiconductors [with] wide-bandgap semiconductors – in particular with silicon carbide.”
Commodity products like SIC semis are always overproduced, driving down prices and profits.

Remember ON products are simple semi-conductors, now becoming a commodity with no barriers to entry, unlike GPUs or CPUs. Many competitors are entering the SIC market because it's easy to produce SIC semis!
Chinese are ramping substrate production and products which will crush ON!Now SIC has many competitors and the end market for EVs is contracting!

bayoubrainhemorrhage-starlardwow you're actually starting to post relevant comments rather than just a baseless hackfest (although your onslaught and fearmongering of a warning and lowball price targets sits in that category).Interestingly, competition in chips is good. ON isn't the only producer of SiC, both STM and IFX are competitors. WOLF is a small competitor but where they have real challenges is the growing cheaper supply of wafers in China. ON, STM, and IFX don't sell wafers to the external market, they produce some wafers internally and buy the rest from suppliers so lower cost on wafers is a benefit to them but it's the end of WOLF. And as ON frequently says, it's not just about the device, it's about the die, packaging, and device.
